name: Arduino Sketch for reading Grove light sensor
info:
- Source code for the Arduino sketch:
  
https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino

- This Arduino sketch reads the sensor data 
  from the Grove light sensor and displays the data. 

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

- When we write Arduino code, normally we don't
  write from scratch. We use the code that's
  provided by the maker of the sensor or
  communications module (Bluetooth, WiFi, Sigfox etc)
 
- The Arduino code here was derived from the 
  official sensor specifications and sample code:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Light_Sensor/

https://github.com/Seeed-Studio/Light_Sensor/blob/master/examples/Light_Sensor/Light_Sensor.ino 

- Check the above links and compare the
  similarity of the code

- We will likely be using various Grove sensors 
  for our project because they are easy to connect.
  Here is the list of Grove sensors available,
  please choose sensors that are compatible with Arduino:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove_System/

- SeeedStudio provides sample Arduino code for Grove Sensors on wiki.seeed.cc, e.g.

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Sound_Sensor/ 

- Every Arduino Sketch has 3 sections: **Declarations, Setup, Loop**. Click the nodes to learn more.

name: Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L31-L54

- Every Arduino program has a **Setup** function
  that is run once upon startup.

- We use this section to initialise the sensor

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

name: Loop
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L56-L76

- Every Arduino sketch has a **Loop** function
  that is run repeatedly after **Setup.**  

- Here we read the sensor value from the Arduino
  light sensor and display it

- The light sensor should be connected to 
  **Port A0** of the Grove Shield.  This is
  an **Analog Port,** since the light sensor
  is an analog sensor.

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

-  When running with a real Sigfox shield,
   we should insert a delay of 10 seconds 
   at the end of the `loop()` function.
   We should not send more than 1 message
   within 10 seconds.

name: General Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L32-L39

- We declare the **Setup** function as `void setup()`.
  This means it accepts no parameters and 
  returns no values.  In C++, functions start
  with `{` and end with `}`.

- When we use the **Serial Monitor** we are
  actually connecting through our computer's
  COM serial port to the USB interface to
  another serial port located on the Arduino board.
  The Arduino's serial port is also known as 
  **UART - Universal Asynchronous Receiver / Transmitter**

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_asynchronous_receiver/transmitter

- In most Arduino sketches we use the serial
  port to display debug messages. That's why
  the serial port is connected to the
  Serial Monitor

- By convention, we use 9,600 bits per second
  to connect to the serial port.  This is set
  through `Serial.begin(9600)`

- We use `Serial.println` to output messages
  to the serial port / Serial Monitor.
  This section will print `Running setup...`
  when the sketch starts running.

- Why did we call function `F(...)`? Because
  RAM is severely limited. By calling `F(...)`
  we store the `Running setup...` string
  in **Flash Memory** instead of RAM, 
  so we have more usable memory.  

- When you compile a sketch you may see:

```
Sketch uses 19,168 bytes (59%) of program storage space. Maximum is 32,256 bytes.
Global variables use 1,376 bytes (67%) of dynamic memory, leaving 672 bytes for local variables. Maximum is 2,048 bytes.
```

- That means the Arduino Uno has only **2KB of usuable RAM**.
  The sketch occupies 19KB of Flash Memory, which is a lot bigger
  than available RAM.

name: Sensor Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L41-L47

- There is no sensor setup needed for the Grove Light Sensor.

- Some smart sensors (e.g. air pressure sensor)
  may need some time to start up and warm up.

name: Sigfox Module Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L41-L47

- This will be used to initialise the Sigfox
  module before transmitting Sigfox messages

name: Sensor Loop
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L57-L65

- In this section we read the sensor data.

- `int light_level` declares an Integer variable
  named `light_level` which we will use
  to save the sensor value

- `light_level = analogRead(LIGHT_SENSOR)` reads
  the value of Analog Port 0, i.e. A0.
  We declared `LIGHT_SENSOR` to be `A0`
  in the **General Declarations** section

- All C++ statements must end with `;`

- Then we print the `light_level` to the
  serial port / Serial Monitor

- Why didn't we call `F(...)` for `light_level`?
  Because `light_level` is a variable and
  can't be stored in Flash Memory, which is
  read-only. `F(...)` should be called for
  text strings that never change.

name: Sigfox Module Loop
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L67-L71

- We'll use this section in the next Practical
  to send the sensor data via Sigfox

name: Loop Delay
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L73-L75

- Remember that we are not supposed to send
  2 Sigfox messages within 10 seconds.  In fact
  the guideline is that we should only send
  maximum 140 messages in a day.

- Also we shouldn't read sensors too often. This drains
  the battery faster.

- By calling `delay(10000)` we introduce a
  10-second delay into the loop.  We specify
  10,000 because the unit is milliseconds,
  so 10 seconds = 10000 milliseconds

- So the program pauses here for 10 seconds
  before running `loop()` again

- Unlike normal computers, a microcontroller
  like Arduino doesn't know how to end / exit / quit!
  It will happily run `loop()` forever
  until you disconnect the power.

name: Declarations
info:
- Click to see the section: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L1-L29

- All Arduino programs have a **Declarations** section
  at the beginning to declare any required
  library functions or global constants / variables

- An Arduino Sketch is a C++ program, so we
  use `//` and `/* ... */` to denote comments

name: Sensor Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L11-L23

- Here we declare any library functions, constants
  and variables used by the sensor

- The Grove Light Sensor uses the standard
  Analog port and doesn't require any libraries

- The `#ifdef ... #endif` is a C++ Preprocessor
  Directive. During the C++ compilation, the
  C++ compiler checks whether we are compiling
  for the Bean Arduino Device, and if so
  use port A2 instead of the default A0 for
  connecting to the light sensor.  We are
  using the Arduino Uno, so `LIGHT_SENSOR`
  will be set to `A0`.

name: Sigfox Module Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L25-L29

- This section will be used in the next Practical
  to declare the library functions, constants
  and variables needed for the Sigfox transmission

name: General Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L1-L9

- This is a comment (marked by `//`) that describes the program
  features. 

- The connections for the Arduino Pins is
  described in Exercise 1

name: Device
info:
- The components below represent a real IoT device
  (e.g. Arduino Uno) or a simulated IoT device.

- We organise the components here according to the 
  Arduino programming convention

- All Arduino programs start execution at the `setup()` 
  function. The `setup()` function is called once
  to perform any device or sensor initialisation.

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

- The `loop()` function is called repeatedly
  to allow the Arduino program to perform any required
  tasks.  A typical `loop()` function will:

0. Read data from a sensor.
1. Process the data read. Possibly encode to save space.
2. Transmit the data e.g. over Sigfox. 
3. Delay a few seconds before restarting the loop

-  The Sigfox shield will not allow two transmissions within 10 seconds.
   So it's a good practice to insert a delay of 10 seconds at 
   the end of the `loop()` function.

name: Setup
info:
- **Setup** is run once upon startup.  Corresponds
  to the `setup()` function in Arduino sketches.

- The flow starts running with value 500, i.e.
  light was detected. This value is injected
  every 10 seconds.

- Pressing the inject button for **"light level = 0"**
  will switch the sensor to send value 0
  every 10 seconds.

- Pressing the inject button for **"light level = 500"**
  will switch the sensor to send value 500
  every 10 seconds.

name: Loop
info:
- **Loop** is run repeatedly after **Setup.**  Corresponds
  to the `loop()` function in Arduino sketches.

- Injects the sensor value 0 or 500 into the flow
  depending on the button that was pressed above.

- The sensor value is injected every 10 seconds.

- The **"Connect To Transmit"** node should be
  connected to the **Transmit** node for the
  sensor value to be injected into the flow.

- No other nodes should be connected to the
  **Transmit** node

name: Transmit
info:
- In the **Transmit** stage, the sensor data
  is transmitted to the **IoT Gateway.**

- When the Arduino board is used with a **Sigfox
  Shield,** the sensor data will be broadcast
  3 times on different frequencies (Frequency Hopping)

- Nearby **Sigfox Basestations** that receive
  the message will forward it to the **Sigfox Cloud.**

- If the message was received by 2 or more
  basestations, the Sigfox Cloud marks the
  duplicate messages with a **"Duplicate"** flag.
  The IoT Gateway may be configured to accept or
  reject duplicate messages.

name: IoT Gateway
info:
- The **IoT Gateway** resides in the **IoT Cloud**
  and is responsible for receiving sensor data messages
  and forwarding them to the **Rule Engine** for processing.

- In an upcoming practical, we shall adopt **AWS IoT**
  as the IoT Cloud.  The IoT Gateway shall be
  the **MQTT Message Queue Gateway** in **AWS IoT.**

name: Rule Engine
info:
- The **Rule Engine** is the component in the
  Cloud IoT platform (e.g. AWS IoT, Azure IoT)
  that executes rules to process any sensor
  data received.

- Most Cloud IoT platforms support `if ... then ... else ... `
  kind of rules. A rule could trigger an **alert** 
  (e.g. email, SMS alerts),
  update a **database** (for rendering dashboards)
  or execute an **external service** (e.g. predict
  sensor values based on machine learning)

- In this example the rules update the **Physical
  and Logical Device States** to record the
  variables needed for business logic e.g.
  "Is the light on?" "What time did the light turn off?"

name: Alerts
info:
- **Alerts** are notifications to a person or to
  another system, triggered by rules in the **Rule Engine.**

- In **AWS IoT** we will learn to send alerts for
  **email, SMS and automated voice call.**

name: Dashboard
info:
- The **Dashboard** renders realtime data from the
  **Physical and Logical Device States.**

- When designing a **Dashboard,** think carefully
  what information we need to present in order
  to derive the most value.

- For example, showing a chart of **Light Level**
  against time wouldn't be as useful as the number
  of **Light Failures** per day / week / month.

name: Sensor
info:
- The components below represent a real IoT 
  sensor (e.g. Grove light sensor) 
  or a simulated IoT sensor.

- The Sensor marks the start of the IoT flow.
  Sensor values are injected into the flow
  every 10 seconds.

- The Sensor values will be transmitted to
  the IoT Gateway and processed according
  to the rules in the Rule Engine.

- Historical Sensor values will be recorded
  into the Sensor data store for analytics
  and possibly machine learning.

name: Sensor Data Store
info:
- The **Sensor Data Store** keeps a historical
  record of every sensor data record, i.e. the
  past and present **Physical Device States.**

- It also stores all past and present **Logical Device States**
  that have been computed by the system. 

- The **Sensor Data Store** will enable business
  reports and **Dashboards** to be created across
  various time periods (e.g. by hour, by day, by week).

- Such reports and dashboards will require past
  and present data to be aggregated across time period
  (e.g. one week)in an efficient way. Also we
  may not be required to generate detailed past reports 
  beyond a certain number of days.

- For these reasons, a **Time Series Database** (like
  **InfluxDB**) may be more suitable for storing
  historical IoT data.  A **Time Series Database**
  allows sensor data to be aggregated efficient across
  time periods, and supports auto-archival of old
  sensor data.

- Since the sensor data volume is low for our projects, 
  we shall be using **MySQL hosted at AWS** to store
  and query our sensor data in subsequent lessons.

- Also since many of us are familiar with **MySQL,**
  it helps to speed up the development of reports,
  dashboards and mobile apps.

- For the simulation we shall be appending records to
  the text
  files **physical-device-state.json** and
  **logical-device-state.json,** which are located
  in the `c:/users/username/.node-red` folder.

name: IoT Analytics
info:
- With **Wide IoT** and **LPWAN** becoming available everywhere,
  we will see many more IoT devices deployed.

- Processing the sensor data from so many IoT devices
  will become a serious challenge unless we had
  tools for **IoT Analytics**

- Tools for **IoT Analytics** can process large volumes of
  data at very affordable prices. A good example
  is **Google BigQuery,** a data warehouse that can manage huge
  volumes of data with just a few dollars of 
  data hostinf charges per month.

name: IoT Machine Learning
info:
- After gathering sufficient sensor data in the
  **Sensor Data Store**, it may be possible to
  run a **Machine Learning** program to learn 
  the patterns of the historical sensor data
  and predict future sensor data.

- For example, we may use past light sensor data
  to predict when a light is most likely to fail.

- **Machine Learning** may also be used to detect
  anomalies in the sensor data. For example, it
  may help to identify cases where the Arduino
  device is down, due to the huge lapse of missing
  sensor data.

- Some applications use **Machine Learning** to
  perform automated classification of data,
  e.g. credit card fraud detection.

name: Deep IoT
info:
- **Deep IoT** refers to devices that tend
  to do more processing locally, so the require
  more network bandwidth, more power

- **Amazon Echo / Alexa** is a good example.
  It performs some audio processing locally
  and it uses WiFi to send/receive data.
  It's not meant to run on battery power.

- This has been the traditional model for
  IoT: smart, localised devices that have
  constraints on location, power, network
  connectivity.

- **Deep IoT** has also been noted to have a
  higher Total Cost of Ownership because
  more things can go wrong locally.  Think
  about a Raspberry Pi and the possibility
  that its SD card could be corrupted beyond repair.
  Compare that with an Arduino Uno that has
  no filesystem.

- In this course we'll focus on a more challenging
  and impactful class of IoT devices called
  **Wide IoT** devices that have much fewer
  constraints on location, power and 
  network connectivity

name: Wide IoT
info:
- In this course we'll focus on a more challenging
  and impactful class of IoT devices called
  **Wide IoT** devices that have much fewer
  constraints on location, power and 
  network connectivity

- **Wide IoT** devices are designed for
  widespread deployment. They use 
  **Low Power Wide Area Networks (LPWAN)** like 
  **Sigfox, LoRa, NB-IoT**

- They are designed to run on battery power,
  up to months and years of battery life.
  The networks are available city-wide, e.g.
  most parts of Singapore are already covered
  by Sigfox.  So the devices will work anywhere
  without a power outlet.

- The **Arduino Uno with UnaShield Sigfox Shield**
  makes a good device for **Wide IoT** because
  it runs on battery power and can transmit
  sensor data from most areas in Singapore.

- **Wide IoT** devices like the 
  **Arduino Uno with UnaShield** also tend
  to be lower in cost than **Deep IoT** devices.

- The Total Cost of Ownership of these devices
  tend to be lower because they have fewer
  components that may cause problems

name: Mobile App
info:
- Depending on the nature of the IoT application,
  a **Mobile App (Android/iOS)** may be necessary.

- In the streetlight monitoring example,
  a field staff who is dispatched to repair
  a faulty light may need to use the Mobile App
  to check on the history of faults.  

- Or the
  field staff may use the mobile app to
  test whether the streetlight monitoring
  device is sending the right data to the
  IoT Cloud.

- **Slack** could be the simplest option for
  mobile access. Slack is suitable for
  observing realtime messages generated by
  a device.  Slack commands may also be
  programmed to control or configure a 
  device if necessary.  We will explore the Slack
  integration in a future practical.

- A **Mobile Website** could also be used.
  It offers more flexibility than Slack
  but the UI may not be as rich as a native mobile
  app. Consider using the **React Web** framework
  for creating your mobile website.
  
- For the best mobile experience while
  maintaining the same code base across
  Android and iOS, consider **React Native.**

- IoT Platforms like **AWS IoT** allow sensor
  data and functions to be exposed as
  **REST/JSON services,** so that the mobile apps
  may consume them. For AWS IoT, the
  standard way to expose sensor data and
  functions is to use **AWS API Gateway.**

name: Physical Device State
info:
-- The **Physical Device State** contains the 
   sensor values before executing any rules
   in the Rule Engine.
   
-- In **AWS IoT** the **Physical Device State** is
   also known as the **Device Shadow,** because it
   remembers (shadows) the last known state of the device
   (e.g. Arduino Uno) and its sensors (e.g. Light Sensor).
   
-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on (`light_detected = true / false`). 
   `light_detected` is stored in the **Logical Device State.**
   
-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on.
   
-- In this simulation, the **Physical Device State**
   is stored in a variable named `last_physical_device_state`
   in the Node-RED flow context.

name: Logical Device State
info:
-- The **Logical Device State** contains the 
   sensor values before executing any rules
   in the Rule Engine.
   
-- The rules in the Rule Engine may make use of the
   **Physical Device State** to derive the
   **Logical Device State,** which is more
   business-oriented

-- In this simulation, the rules in the Rule Engine
   will read the **Physical Device State** to get the
   light sensor value and compute whether the light
   is on (`light_detected = true / false`). 
   `light_detected` is stored in the **Logical Device State.**

-- The second set of rules below will read the
   `light_detected` status from the **Logical Device State**
   and compute `light_off_timestamp`, `light_off_duration`,
   which will be stored in the **Logical Device State**
   
-- In this simulation, the **Logical Device State**
   is stored in a variable named `last_logical_device_state`
   in the Node-RED flow context.

name: transmit
convert to json
toggle output on input
save physical device state
display
save logical device state
Simulated Sensor
info:
- This sensor simulates a light sensor for
  a streetlight monitoring system.

- The sensor returns either 500, to represent
  the detection of light, or 0 to represent
  the absence of light.

- The flow starts running with value 500, i.e.
  light was detected. This value is injected
  every 10 seconds.

- Pressing the inject button for **"light level = 0"**
  will switch the sensor to send value 0
  every 10 seconds.

- Pressing the inject button for **"light level = 500"**
  will switch the sensor to send value 500
  every 10 seconds.

name: Arduino Sensor
info:
- This sensor connects to a real Arduino Uno
  via USB/serial port and reads the value 
  of the Grove light sensor connected to the
  Uno.

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

- The Arduino Uno must be running the
  **StandardFirmataPlus** sketch.  This is a
  remote control program that receives 
  commands from Node-RED via USB/serial port,
  executes them and returns the results.

- Uses the **Johnny5 Arduino** module.  We selected
  this module over the basic Node-RED Arduino 
  module because it supports more Arduino
  functions.

name: current physical device state
current logical device state
display
Setup
info:
- **Setup** is run once upon startup.  Corresponds
  to the `setup()` function in Arduino sketches.

- **Setup** is empty when the Arduino Uno is
  controlled by Node-RED over StandardFirmataPlus.

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

- The `setup()` function should also
  initialise the Arduino sensor.

name: Loop
info:
- **Loop** is run repeatedly after **Setup.**  Corresponds
  to the `loop()` function in Arduino sketches.

- Reads the sensor value from the Arduino
  light sensor and injects the value into the
  flow.

- The light sensor should be connected to 
  **Port A0** of the Grove Shield.  This is
  an **Analog Port,** since the light sensor
  is an analog sensor.

- The sensor value is injected every 10 seconds.

- The **"Connect To Transmit"** node should be
  connected to the **Transmit** node for the
  sensor value to be injected into the flow.

- No other nodes should be connected to the
  **Transmit** node

- We flash the LED on Arduino pin D13 every
  10 seconds, to provide feedback that the
  flow is running. The Arduino Uno has
  an onboard LED (coloured orange) on
  pin D13.

-  When running with a real Sigfox shield,
   we should insert a delay of 10 seconds 
   at the end of the `loop()` function.
   We should not send more than 1 message
   within 10 seconds.

name: tick
tick
tick
tick
tick
tick
tick
tick

ðŸ†•  - Arduino Sketch for sending light sensor data to Sigfox
info:
- Source code for the Arduino sketch:
  
https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/send-light-level/send-light-level.ino

- This Arduino sketch reads the sensor data 
  from the Grove light sensor and sends the data
  to the Sigfox network. 

- The sensor value is read every 10 seconds.

- When we write Arduino code, normally we don't
  write from scratch. We use the code that's
  provided by the maker of the sensor or
  communications module (Bluetooth, WiFi, Sigfox etc)
 
- The Arduino code here was derived from the 
  official sensor specifications and sample code:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Light_Sensor/

https://github.com/Seeed-Studio/Light_Sensor/blob/master/examples/Light_Sensor/Light_Sensor.ino 

- Check the above links and compare the
  similarity of the code

  for our project because they are easy to connect.
  Here is the list of Grove sensors available,
  please choose sensors that are compatible with Arduino:

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove_System/

- SeeedStudio provides sample Arduino code for Grove Sensors on wiki.seeed.cc, e.g.

http://wiki.seeed.cc/Grove-Sound_Sensor/ 

- Every Arduino Sketch has 3 sections: **Declarations, Setup, Loop**. Click the nodes to learn more.

info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L31-L54

- Every Arduino program has a **Setup** function
  that is run once upon startup.

- We use this section to initialise the sensor

- When using a Sigfox shield with Arduino, we
  normally initialise the Sigfox module in the `setup()` function.
  Some Sigfox modules include a Power Amplifier
  and may need some time to power up.

info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L56-L76

- Every Arduino sketch has a **Loop** function
  that is run repeatedly after **Setup.**  

- Here we read the sensor value from the Arduino

- The light sensor should be connected to 
  **Port A0** of the Grove Shield.  This is
  an **Analog Port,** since the light sensor

-  When running with a real Sigfox shield,
   we should insert a delay of 10 seconds 
   at the end of the `loop()` function.

   within 10 seconds.

name: General Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L32-L39

- We declare the **Setup** function as `void setup()`.
  This means it accepts no parameters and 
  returns no values.  In C++, functions start
  with `{` and end with `}`.

- When we use the **Serial Monitor** we are
  actually connecting through our computer's
  COM serial port to the USB interface to
  another serial port located on the Arduino board.
  The Arduino's serial port is also known as 
  **UART - Universal Asynchronous Receiver / Transmitter**

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_asynchronous_receiver/transmitter

- In most Arduino sketches we use the serial
  port to display debug messages. That's why
  the serial port is connected to the
  Serial Monitor

- By convention, we use 9,600 bits per second
  to connect to the serial port.  This is set
  through `Serial.begin(9600)`

- We use `Serial.println` to output messages
  to the serial port / Serial Monitor.
  This section will print `Running setup...`
  when the sketch starts running.

- Why did we call function `F(...)`? Because
  RAM is severely limited. By calling `F(...)`
  we store the `Running setup...` string
  in **Flash Memory** instead of RAM, 
  so we have more usable memory.  

- When you compile a sketch you may see:

```
Sketch uses 19,168 bytes (59%) of program storage space. Maximum is 32,256 bytes.
Global variables use 1,376 bytes (67%) of dynamic memory, leaving 672 bytes for local variables. Maximum is 2,048 bytes.
```

- That means the Arduino Uno has only **2KB of usuable RAM**.
  The sketch occupies 19KB of Flash Memory, which is a lot bigger
  than available RAM.

name: Sensor Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L41-L47

- There is no sensor setup needed for the Grove Light Sensor.

- Some smart sensors (e.g. air pressure sensor)
  may need some time to start up and warm up.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Setup
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L41-L47

- This will be used to initialise the Sigfox
  module before transmitting Sigfox messages

name: Sensor Loop
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L57-L65

- In this section we read the sensor data.

- `int light_level` declares an Integer variable
  named `light_level` which we will use
  to save the sensor value

- `light_level = analogRead(LIGHT_SENSOR)` reads
  the value of Analog Port 0, i.e. A0.
  We declared `LIGHT_SENSOR` to be `A0`
  in the **General Declarations** section

- All C++ statements must end with `;`

- Then we print the `light_level` to the
  serial port / Serial Monitor

- Why didn't we call `F(...)` for `light_level`?
  Because `light_level` is a variable and
  can't be stored in Flash Memory, which is
  read-only. `F(...)` should be called for
  text strings that never change.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Loop
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L67-L71

- We'll use this section in the next Practical
  to send the sensor data via Sigfox

name: Loop Delay
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L73-L75

- Remember that we are not supposed to send
  2 Sigfox messages within 10 seconds.  In fact
  the guideline is that we should only send
  maximum 140 messages in a day.

- Also we shouldn't read sensors too often. This drains
  the battery faster.

- By calling `delay(10000)` we introduce a
  10-second delay into the loop.  We specify
  10,000 because the unit is milliseconds,
  so 10 seconds = 10000 milliseconds

- So the program pauses here for 10 seconds
  before running `loop()` again

- Unlike normal computers, a microcontroller
  like Arduino doesn't know how to end / exit / quit!
  It will happily run `loop()` forever
  until you disconnect the power.

name: Declarations
info:
- Click to see the section: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L1-L29

- All Arduino programs have a **Declarations** section
  at the beginning to declare any required
  library functions or global constants / variables

- An Arduino Sketch is a C++ program, so we
  use `//` and `/* ... */` to denote comments

name: Sensor Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L11-L23

- Here we declare any library functions, constants
  and variables used by the sensor

- The Grove Light Sensor uses the standard
  Analog port and doesn't require any libraries

- The `#ifdef ... #endif` is a C++ Preprocessor
  Directive. During the C++ compilation, the
  C++ compiler checks whether we are compiling
  for the Bean Arduino Device, and if so
  use port A2 instead of the default A0 for
  connecting to the light sensor.  We are
  using the Arduino Uno, so `LIGHT_SENSOR`
  will be set to `A0`.

name: ðŸ†•  - Sigfox Module Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L25-L29

- This section will be used in the next Practical
  to declare the library functions, constants
  and variables needed for the Sigfox transmission

name: General Declarations
info:
- Click here: https://github.com/UnaBiz/unabiz-arduino/blob/master/examples/read-light-level/read-light-level.ino#L1-L9

- This is a comment (marked by `//`) that describes the program
  features. 

- The connections for the Arduino Pins is
  described in Exercise 1
